creditline: Museum purchase, Kathleen Compton Sherrerd Fund for Acquisitions in American Art
inscribed: in graphite, lower left: Bough apple
signed: Inscribed, signed, and dated in brown ink, lower right: Drawn from Nature by Sarah Hoding | August 1819

makers.displaydate: active ca. 1819; born England; active Philadelphia, PA and Boston, MA
makers.displaymaker: Sarah Hoding, active ca. 1819; born England; active Philadelphia, PA and Boston, MA

texts.textentryhtml:
One of a group of watercolors of fruits by William Allbright (active ca. 1795-after 1850) and Sarah Holding.  Owned by a New York collector, three of which were included in Berry-Hill’s exhibition (see below).  [Allbright was a landscape painter and botanical illustrator and taught drawing classes.  Sarah may have been one of his pupils and further may be wife of Thomas Holding (fl. 1819-25) who knew Allbright and lived a block away.  Obviously, more research is needed.];

Georgiana Hubbard McCabe; purchased from Berry-Hill Galleries, Inc., NY.;

bibliography.boilertext: John Wilmerding et al., American Art in the Princeton University Art Museum: volume 1: drawings and watercolors, (Princeton: Princeton University Art Museum; New Haven, CT; London: Yale University Press, 2004)

bibliography.boilertext: Bruce Weber, The apple of America: the apple in 19th century American art, (New York: Berry-Hill Galleries, 1993).
bibliography.citation: Bruce Weber, The apple of America: the apple in 19th century American art, (New York: Berry-Hill Galleries, 1993)., p. 9; checklist p. 47; p. 30, fig 6
